I have reinstalled from CVS and included this method in my code.  However, =
I still end up 
with the same results (flame speed and temp) with and witho=
ut thermal diffusion.  
Thinking it may be my code, I also ran flame2.py wi=
th and without thermal diffusion and 
arrived at the same results.  I belie=
ve I've downloaded from CVS correctly as I have the new 
version of flame2.=
py, which includes 'enableSoret()'.  Must this line (and those associated 
=
with it) be turned 'off' or can it simply be commented out?  In the cases I=
've run, I've 
commented them out.  Is there something else I'm missing?

T=
hanks.
Rusty   

--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@..=
.> wrote:
>
> I looked into this, and much to my surprise it seems you can'=
t turn  
> on thermal diffusion in flame simulations from Python or MATLAB.=
 It  
> works from C++.  In an older version of the Cantera Python interfac=
e,  
> this capability existed, but somehow it was left out when part of  
=
> this interface was rewritten.  I have now put it in.
> 
>  From Python, y=
ou can call a method 'enableSoret()' that turns on  
> thermal diffusion. T=
his change has been checked into the CVS  
> repository. See example flame2=
.py where this is used.
> 
> 
> 
> On Apr 22, 2007, at 10:38 AM, rustoleump=
 wrote:
> 
> > Does anyone know if the diffusion effects (Soret, Dufour, et=
c) are  
> > enabled automatically
> > with the multicomponent transport?  =
I'm using the freely  
> > propagating adiabatic flame
> > example with an =
H2-O2 mechanism and I'm not able to match the flame  
> > speed with the
> =
> literature.  My results are about 7% too high.  When I checked the  
> > =
source code, I found the
> > line m_do_soret(false) in the file StFlow.cpp =
and it seems to me  
> > that this would force the
> > Soret effect to be o=
ff.  I've run the same grid with multicomponent  
> > and mixture averaged
=
> > transport with different results - the mixture averaged is slightly  
>=
 > higher as I would expect.
> > I have changed the line to m_do_soret(true=
), recompiled and it  
> > didn't change the result.  I
> > appreciate any =
help.
> >
> > Thanks.
> > Rusty
